Comment: It's a simple enough problem that is a good test of programming skills.

Comment: good clash to practice some basic math and logic with code :)

Input section
* Please do not format the whole line 1 description in bold. Just format "line 1" and "line 2" in bold.

* Please change "two numbers" to "two space-separated integers" (two times).

* Please change a, b, c, d to A, B, C, D for consistency.

* Please change "a/b" and "c/d" to "A/B" and "C/D" for consistency.

* Please remove the last line, as it just repeats which has been stated in Constraints section.

Output section
* Please change "two numbers" to "two space-separated integers".

* It is weird to format "found" in bold.

* Please format E and F as [[variables]].

Constraints section
* I don't think B and D can be 0. In fact, as you don't have 0 as part of the input in all the cases, just change 0 to 1.

Thanks.

I like this clash, I think it deserve a little bit more formatting for the statement and all but it's good. For the input section, I believe the rule is to write Line 1 and Line 2 in bold but not the following, but even if I'm wrong you should write the two lines the same way.
I think "Simplest form" are not the best words to use, wouldn't it be better to use a reduced or irreductible fraction ?
That last remark ain't an issue, but maybe you could consider the input and the output to be slash-separated integers.

first of all, you should add "e/f should be in the simplest form".

second of all, this would just be simplifying a/b+c/d, since a/b+c/d would only have one answer. So essentially this clash is just testing if people know how to simplify fractions with the coding language of their choice.

let me try to help 5DN1L do his job a bit :)

goal:
*make all constant formatting into variable formatting -> {{A/B}} -> [[A/B]]

Input: 
*please bold "line 1" and "line 2" -> <<line 1>> 
*Please use the variable formation for c and d in line 2 -> [[c]] [[d]]
*change "contains two numbers" to "Two integers"
*remove the constrain
*make the constant formatting to variable formatting -> {{a/b}} -> [[a/b]]
*change a,b,c,d to A,B,C,D for consistency 

Output:
*make E and F into variable format instead of constant format -> {{E}} -> [[E]]
*change it to <<Line 1:>> two integers [[E]] and [[F]] separated by space

These are the ones I can find, I'll leave the rest to 5DN1L

It is not clear enough, what does it mean "E/F is the smallest fraction."

Do you mean "F is the smallest positive number?"
I think they meant out of fractions A/B, C/D, and E/F, E/F has to be the smallest.
Thank you for your comment. I agree with your comments and have edited the title according to your request :3!

thank you for your opinion, first of all, i respect and agree with your first opinion because it makes perfect sense, i will try to use the correct technical terms as i have no training in english 1 standard way.
Next, your second opinion I find unreasonable, because my second condition creates for everyone to use a greatest common divisor (gcd) correctly and fluently. moreover it's a basic knowledge in math so i think everyone can do it :3!

thanks for your comments, I changed lines 1 and 2 to 2 bold lines 10 minutes ago, and added test and received comments such as using the word incorrect (because I'm not trained in standard English terms like you guys) so I changed from "Simplest form" to ""reduced fraction".
Once again I would like to thank you for your comments :3!
Thanks for your comments, I've edited it as requested :3!
thank you so much!
thank you so much
thank you so much

Well simplest form isn't really wrong though, Wikipedia itself says: An irreducible fraction (or fraction in lowest terms, simplest form or reduced fraction)
I just feel it's weird but I'm not a native speaker myself.

That is a fair opinion. I am interested in seeing this, I'll upvote it :)

(I should also go to sleep now its 2:19am for me :sob:

thank you very muchhhhh <3
fun fact: Right now I send this message at 6:51 p.m :))

I have updated my comment a bit. Also, bold both "line 1" and "line 2" in the input section, but only bold those words and not the whole sentence. 


<<line 1 contains two numbers [[a]] and [[b]]>> -> <<line 1>> contains two integer [[a]] and [[b]]
do that for line 2 as well ^
Thanks Storm_Blackthorn for your help (although my user name is spelled wrong ðŸ¤ª)!

Thank you for your comments :3!
I will fix it a bit at line 1 and line 2 input :))
opps ;-;

yes, E/F has to be the smallest.
I will pay attention to my word usage, thank you for your comments :3!
